Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Historical and contemporary influences on elevational distributions and biodiversity tested in tropical Asia
Award.AbstractNarration:
The causes of geographical gradients in biodiversity are not well understood, and remain a major scientific challenge. Many physical and biotic factors may influence the evolutionary diversification and species distribution dynamics that result in these gradients. This study examines an elevational gradient of tropical birds in Asia, where functional, genetic, and phylogenetic diversity of organisms are woefully understudied and underlying patterns provide a strong system for testing hypotheses about biodiversity along elevational gradients. The proposed research evaluates both traditional (physiological tolerance, competition, opposing boundaries) and novel (taxon age, adult survival, life history trade-offs) factors that vary along elevational gradients and integrates them with dispersal, genetic structure, and phylogenetic history.

The research partners will share samples and data, and collaborate in cross-disciplinary training of students, in pursuing tests of the proposed hypotheses. This integration will lead to a new mechanistic understanding and conceptual framework for the influence of physical climate gradients and biotic interactions on species distributions and the evolution of diversity. The project will provide extensive opportunities for the training of undergraduate and graduate students, including a unique cross-cultural life experience as well as hands-on educational and field experience. Public outreach includes work with high school students and teachers, museum exhibits, and development of an educational video on tropical bird nesting behaviors. Finally, this project has critical conservation ramifications, as tropical Asian forests are being lost at the fastest rate of any tropical forests in the world, and this research will provide critical information on possible climate change impacts that are of grave concern to extinction risks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tropical bird and other animal species exhibit discrete elevational ranges on tropical mountains, with distributions of related species often adjacent to each other up the mountain. These discrete distributions are associated with changing temperatures along elevational gradients and provide a unique opportunity to examine the underlying causes of distributions of related species.

        We explored hypotheses across songbird species in tropical Asia in Kinabalu National Park, Malaysia at 6 degrees N latitude at elevations 1400 – 3200 m. We identified malarial infections in a large sample of birds across the elevational gradient based on DNA analyses. We found highly variable infection rates across species and high levels of infection in babblers compared to other songbirds we assessed. We are currently assessing a hypothesis proposed in other systems that distributions of parasite species vary with elevation and may impact the elevational distribution of avian host species. We produced a new phylogeny for the songbird species on Borneo and showed that the phylogenetic composition and functional morphological traits of bird communities supported long-standing arguments that competition was more important in the species composition of lower elevation communities and physiological tolerances were more important in high elevation communities. Yet, contrary to long-standing arguments, playback experiments indicated that aggressive interactions, as a reflection of competition, did not explain elevational distributions of related species. Metabolic responses to decreasing temperatures indicated that physiological tolerances did not explain elevational distributions, contrary to expectations. Moreover, metabolic rates were not slower than north temperate species from Arizona, USA, contrary to long-standing hypotheses. However, metabolic rates were predicted by adult survival rates within each latitude, but not between latitudes. We showed that intensity of field methods had a major influence on accuracy of estimates and that the most extensively used methods were under-estimating survival in tropical birds. We used heating experiments to show that embryos were sensitive to temperature in their development rates and species differed in their sensitivity, but temperature sensitivities did not explain differences in elevational distributions. Parents were a critical modifier of temperatures to which embryos were exposed through incubation behaviors, and parents of species with higher survival and longer life put less effort into warming embryos and causing longer embryonic periods that exposed the embryos to higher risk of predation. Risk of predation among species influenced how fast the young grew after hatching, but we show that counter to long-standing perspectives, tropical species do not grow slower than temperate species when considered over the entire nestling period and, in fact, grow their wings faster than north temperate species. We also show for the first time that higher predation risk was associated with shorter periods in the nest which influenced locomotor performance at fledging (leaving the nest) which predicted the survival probability of young after leaving the nest. Local adaptations are influenced by gene flow and genetic variation. We developed DNA markers for the birds in the community and are using them to examine genetic variation and dispersal rates among the species.  We found, based on DNA analyses of social babbler family groups, that extra-pair mating was substantially higher than expected for tropical birds under conventional wisdom. Extra-pair parents were not relatives, suggesting that such breeding behaviors increase gene flow. We also found, using DNA sexing, that most of the songbird species in the community had broods of nestlings that were biased in favor of females, suggesting the potential for differences in mortality between sexes after leaving the nest, a previously undescribed phenomena in the tropics. Ultimately, this work has substantially shifted understanding of the causes of variation in physiology, life history, genetic, and phylogenetic diversification in tropical organisms.  

Broader impacts

The project provided support for 6 PhD students, of which 4 have completed their degree requirements. Besides the 6 graduate students, the project also supported > 100 individuals in the field and lab, with most being undergraduate students, but also including post-undergraduate individuals preparing to apply for graduate school, and Malaysians. These individuals included about 50% females, some minorities, and five Malaysians. Students and field assistants were trained in a wide variety of field techniques, and taken through the theory of the science underlying the research being conducted, as well as strong inference science reasoning based on powerpoint presentations. Students were involved with and included as coauthors on numerous publications to facilitate their learning about scientific publishing.

A powerpoint presentation was made to National Park personnel, and members of the tourism board in Sabah, Malaysia.  We also developed short YouTube videos of bird breeding behavior from the site to engage the general public:  http://www.youtube.com/user/BirdNestingBehavior  We continue to develop these videos.  We also developed a public blog, where each of the field assistants wrote a weekly blog about their experiences at the field site to further engage the public. Finally, results are being made available through peer-reviewed publications.
